title: Minions: Cost-efficient Collaboration Between On-device and Cloud Language Models
author: Avanika Narayan (Stanford University), Dan Biderman (Stanford University), Sabri Eyuboglu (Stanford University), Avner May (Stanford University), Scott Linderman (Stanford University), James Zou (Stanford University), Christopher Ré (Stanford University), ...
relevance_why: The paper explores innovative protocols for collaboration between small on-device models and large cloud models, which could inform future work in efficient model deployment across different domains, including audio processing tasks.
background: Collaborative systems where a small on-device language model interacts with a larger cloud model to efficiently solve complex tasks that demand extensive reasoning over a large context.
contribution: Minions introduces MinionS, a novel communication protocol enhancing local-remote model collaboration to achieve over 97.9% of the performance of remote-only systems while dramatically reducing costs by 5.7 times.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often relied on inefficient or naive communication protocols between models, which led to suboptimal performance or high operational costs.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon such approaches by allowing the remote model to decompose tasks into smaller subtasks that are executed locally, enabling parallel processing and better context management.

key_innovation: MinionS protocol's unique approach of task decomposition allows smaller local models to handle complex instructions via parallelism, significantly boosting efficiency and performance.
real_world_impact: This framework has the potential to make language models more accessible and cost-effective, paving the way for broader adoption in practical applications like document analysis and financial reasoning.

new_terms.MinionS: **MinionS** is an enhanced local-remote language model communication protocol that decomposes complex tasks into smaller, manageable subtasks executed in parallel by local models to improve efficiency.
new_terms.task decomposition: **Task decomposition** refers to breaking down a complex task into simpler sub-tasks, which can be independently processed, allowing for improved parallel computation.
